GitHub Copilot (GitHub Copilot) GitHub Actions (GitHub, Inc.) Python (Microsoft) Useful links Python Miniconda Documentation Google Colab How to use this repository Below are the steps you need to follow: Create a GitHub account if you don’t have one. Fork this repository to your account. Enable the Issues tab: Go to the Settings tab and check the Issues option. Add your professor as a collaborator: Go to the Settings tab and add their GitHub username in the Collaborators section. Install python: Download Source Code & WWW GitHub repo WWW Where can I find the problems? Please visit the Mathematics Physics Lectures website. Physics Mathematics Discret Mathematics

docs.text: Problem 1 Theoretical Foundation Equations of Motion: A Fundamental Approach Projectile motion can be analyzed by decomposing it into horizontal and vertical components, based on Newton’s Second Law: 𝐹 ⃗ = 𝑚 𝑎 ⃗ F =m a where 𝐹 ⃗ F is the force, 𝑚 m is the mass, and 𝑎 ⃗ a is the acceleration of the projectile. Horizontal Motion: Constant Velocity Assuming no air resistance, no net force acts horizontally, so the horizontal velocity remains constant: 𝑣 𝑥 = 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) v x ​ =v 0 ​ cos(θ) The horizontal displacement over time 𝑡 t is: 𝑥 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑡 x(t)=v 0 ​ cos(θ)t Vertical Motion: Accelerated Motion Due to Gravity Gravity acts vertically downward with acceleration 𝑔 g: 𝑎 𝑦 = − 𝑔 a y ​ =−g Integrating acceleration with respect to time yields: 𝑣 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) − 𝑔 𝑡 v y ​ (t)=v 0 ​ sin(θ)−gt 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑡 − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 y(t)=v 0 ​ sin(θ)t− 2 1 ​ gt 2 Time of Flight The projectile lands when 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 0 y(t)=0. Solving: 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑡 − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 = 0 v 0 ​ sin(θ)t− 2 1 ​ gt 2 =0 Factoring: 𝑡 ( 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 ) = 0 t(v 0 ​ sin(θ)− 2 1 ​ gt)=0 Solutions: 𝑡 0 t=0 (launch) 𝑡 2 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑔 t= g 2v 0 ​ sin(θ) ​ (total time of flight) Horizontal Range 𝑅 R Substitute total time into horizontal motion equation: 𝑅 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) ⋅ 2 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑔 R=v 0 ​ cos(θ)⋅ g 2v 0 ​ sin(θ) ​ Using identity sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) = 2 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) sin(2θ)=2sin(θ)cos(θ): 𝑅 𝑣 0 2 sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) 𝑔 R= g v 0 2 ​ sin(2θ) ​ Key Insights Maximum range occurs at 𝜃 = 45 ∘ θ=45 ∘ Symmetry: 𝜃 θ and 90 ∘ − 𝜃 90 ∘ −θ yield the same range Quadratic dependence: 𝑅 ∝ 𝑣 0 2 R∝v 0 2 ​ ; doubling 𝑣 0 v 0 ​ quadruples the range Analysis of the Range Effect of Angle of Projection From 𝑅 = 𝑣 0 2 sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) 𝑔 R= g v 0 2 ​ sin(2θ) ​ : Maximum when sin ⁡ ( 2 𝜃 ) = 1 ⇒ 𝜃 = 45 ∘ sin(2θ)=1⇒θ=45 ∘ Same range at complementary angles (e.g., 30 ∘ 30 ∘ and 60 ∘ 60 ∘ ) Effect of Initial Velocity Since 𝑅 ∝ 𝑣 0 2 R∝v 0 2 ​ : Doubling the speed results in a range four times longer High-speed projectiles, like bullets or rockets, travel significantly farther Effect of Gravity The greater the gravitational acceleration 𝑔 g, the shorter the range: 𝑅 ∝ 1 𝑔 R∝ g 1 ​ Example: On the Moon ( 𝑔 ≈ 1.6   m/s 2 g≈1.6m/s 2 ), the range is ~6 times greater than on Earth Practical Applications Sports Soccer: Long passes use angles near 45 ∘ 45 ∘ Basketball: Higher arcs improve the chance of scoring Baseball: Home runs involve optimal launch angles and high initial velocities Engineering & Ballistics Artillery: Cannons are often angled near 45 ∘ 45 ∘ for maximum distance Aerospace: Trajectories must consider gravity, air resistance, and Earth's curvature Effects of Uneven Terrain When the projectile lands at a height different from the launch height (e.g., a hill, valley, or platform), the standard range formula must be adjusted. The vertical motion becomes: 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑦 0 + 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑡 − 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 y(t)=y 0 ​ +v 0 ​ sin(θ)t− 2 1 ​ gt 2 Set 𝑦 ( 𝑡 ) = 𝑦 𝑓 y(t)=y f ​ to solve for time of flight using the quadratic formula: 1 2 𝑔 𝑡 2 − 𝑣 0 sin ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) 𝑡 + ( 𝑦 0 − 𝑦 𝑓 ) = 0 2 1 ​ gt 2 −v 0 ​ sin(θ)t+(y 0 ​ −y f ​ )=0 Solving this equation gives the time(s) when the projectile reaches the final height 𝑦 𝑓 y f ​ . The corresponding horizontal range is then: 𝑅 𝑣 0 cos ⁡ ( 𝜃 ) ⋅ 𝑡 landing R=v 0 ​ cos(θ)⋅t landing ​ Air Resistance and Wind Effects Air Resistance Real projectiles experience drag, a force opposing motion through the air: 𝐹 drag = 1 2 𝐶 𝑑 𝜌 𝐴 𝑣 2 F drag ​ = 2 1 ​ C d ​ ρAv 2 Where: 𝐶 𝑑 C d ​ = drag coefficient 𝜌 ρ = air density 𝐴 A = cross-sectional area 𝑣 v = instantaneous velocity Air resistance causes the trajectory to: Decrease in range Become asymmetrical Flatten at the peak Analytical solutions become impractical; numerical simulations are needed. Wind Effects Tailwind (wind blowing in the direction of motion) increases range Headwind (opposing motion) decreases range Crosswinds can alter the projectile's lateral position Computational Modeling: Python Simulation Below is a Python script that simulates the range as a function of the angle of projection under ideal conditions (no air resistance or wind): python Copy Edit import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt Constants g = 9.81 # Acceleration due to gravity (m/s^2) v0 = 20.0 # Initial velocity (m/s) Angle range from 0 to 90 degrees angles_deg = np.linspace(0, 90, 500) angles_rad = np.radians(angles_deg) Range equation: R = (v0^2 * sin(2θ)) / g ranges = (v0**2 * np.sin(2 * angles_rad)) / g Find maximum range and corresponding angle max_range = np.max(ranges) optimal_angle = angles_deg[np.argmax(ranges)] Plotting plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) plt.plot(angles_deg, ranges, label=f'v0 = {v0} m/s', color='royalblue') plt.axvline(optimal_angle, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Max at {optimal_angle:.1f}°') plt.title('Projectile Range vs Launch Angle') plt.xlabel('Launch Angle (degrees)') plt.ylabel('Range (meters)') plt.grid(True) plt.legend() plt.tight_layout() plt.show() Limitations and Realistic Considerations Assumptions of the Ideal Model: No air resistance Flat terrain (initial and final height are equal) Constant gravity No wind When These Assumptions Fail: In long-distance or high-speed motion, drag significantly affects results In hilly environments, terrain must be accounted for For planetary applications, gravity may not be constant (e.g., large altitudes) Conclusion This exploration of projectile motion demonstrates how range depends on the angle of launch, with the ideal model offering simple and insightful predictions. However, real-world complexities like air resistance, wind, and terrain require more sophisticated modeling using numerical methods. By combining theory with computational tools such as Python, we gain not only a deep understanding of projectile mechanics but also a powerful method to explore real-world applications in sports, engineering, and space science.

Find maximum range and corresponding angle

docs.text: plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) plt.plot(angles_deg, ranges, label=f'v0 = {v0} m/s', color='royalblue') plt.axvline(optimal_angle, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Max at {optimal_angle:.1f}°') plt.title('Projectile Range vs Launch Angle') plt.xlabel('Launch Angle (degrees)') plt.ylabel('Range (meters)') plt.grid(True) plt.legend() plt.tight_layout() plt.show() Limitations and Realistic Considerations Assumptions of the Ideal Model: No air resistance Flat terrain (initial and final height are equal) Constant gravity No wind When These Assumptions Fail: In long-distance or high-speed motion, drag significantly affects results In hilly environments, terrain must be accounted for For planetary applications, gravity may not be constant (e.g., large altitudes) Conclusion This exploration of projectile motion demonstrates how range depends on the angle of launch, with the ideal model offering simple and insightful predictions. However, real-world complexities like air resistance, wind, and terrain require more sophisticated modeling using numerical methods. By combining theory with computational tools such as Python, we gain not only a deep understanding of projectile mechanics but also a powerful method to explore real-world applications in sports, engineering, and space science.
